Avoid using global objects in Constructors and Destructors
Ensure you provide a user-defined copy constructor or disable copy when a class allocates memory in its constructor
Avoid circular references between header files
Avoid base Classes without virtual Destructors
Avoid invocation of virtual Methods of the declared Class in a Constructor or Destructor
Avoid data members that are not private
Avoid using VARIANT Structures
Never throw an exception from a Destructor
Avoid large Files - too many Lines of Code
Avoid large Macros - too many Lines of Code
Avoid implementation files that do not include a header file with the same name
Avoid using memory management Functions (free/malloc/realloc)
Avoid using signals management Functions
Avoid undocumented Header files
Avoid header files with a very low comment/code ratio
Avoid undocumented Implementation files
Avoid Implementation files with a very low comment/code ratio
An include file must contain at most one Class definition
Never define static variables in header files
Avoid Classes with Destructor not explicitly virtual whenever one of its base Class has a virtual Destructor
Avoid functions overriding virtual functions without having the 'virtual' keyword
Ensure you keep simple the design of the component/module to reduce number of independent paths
Avoid Artifacts with High Depth of Code
Avoid Artifacts with too many parameters
Avoid Artifacts with High Essential Complexity
Avoid Artifacts with High Integration Complexity
Avoid Artifacts with High Fan-In
Ensure you reduce the number of referenced Artifacts
Ensure you provide enough comment for your Classes
Avoid Artifacts with lines longer than X characters
Avoid Classes with a High Number Of Children
Avoid Classes with a High Public Data Ratio
Avoid Classes with a High Lack of Cohesion - variant
Avoid Classes with a High Lack of Cohesion
Avoid Classes with High Coupling Between Objects
Avoid Classes with a High Depth of Inheritance Tree
Avoid Classes with High Weighted Methods per Class

Avoid Artifacts with SQL statement including subqueries
Avoid Artifacts with a Complex SELECT Clause
Avoid using GOTO statement
Avoid Artifacts with queries on more than 4 Tables
Ensure to write SQL query with a limited number of tables used in the FROM clause
Ensure all the classes are used
Add comments into interface defintion to explain what is their goal and how they work.
Add comments into functions to explain what is their goal and how they work.
Add comments into method implementation to explain what is their goal and how they work.
Avoid large Artifacts - too many Lines of Code
Avoid undocumented Classes
Ensure your methods are commented enough to provide good understanding to other contributors
Ensure you have used the right prefix for your interface
Ensure all the functions and procedures are used
Ensure all the methods are used
Ensure all the data members are used
Prefer using stored procedure instead of using direct SQL queries to database
Avoid usage of 'std::find_first_of'
Avoid defining Functions with 'struct' or 'class' parameters passed by value
Abstract Classes should be non copy-assignable
Avoid redeclaring and overriding Methods with different default parameter values
Avoid Constructors not supplying an initial value for all non-static data members
Override all overloads of a base Class virtual Method
Ensure you have a number of local methods and remote methods called by methods in the Class below a predefined threshold
Avoid includes in Header Files
Never use strcat() function (C/C++)
Never use strcpy() function (C/C++)
Never use sprintf() or vsprintf() functions
Never use gets() function
Avoid using the scanf() function family
Avoid using strtrns() function
Avoid using strlen() function family
Avoid using strecpy() function
Avoid using streadd() function
DEPRECATED: Avoid using snprintf() function family
Avoid using realpath() function
Avoid using getpass() function
Avoid using getopt() function
Provide a private default Constructor for utility Classes or use free Functions in a Namespace
Avoid local variables that are not initialized at declaration time
Avoid 'catch-all' statement
Never perform C-style cast between incompatible Class pointers
Avoid using 'delete this'
Avoid Classes with a copy Constructor and the default Destructor or assignment operator
Avoid data members that are never read
Do not overload the ampersand, comma, logical AND or logical OR operators
Ensure you don't overwrite member of a class in its subclass.
Avoid Classes with a non-empty Destructor and the default assignment operator or copy Constructor
Avoid Classes with an assignment operator and the default Destructor or copy constructor
Ensure you don't forget the default clause in your switch statement
Ensure you don't use break statement in FOR loops
Do not return non-const handles to Class data from const member Functions
Invoke 'delete' with the same form as the matching 'new'
Do not hide declarations in other scopes
Avoid setting a pointer to the address of a local variable defined in a lower scope
Avoid calling blocking functions with an infinite timeout
Method override fails due to mismatch of const/volatile qualifiers
A pointer to a derived Class shall only be cast implicitly to a pointer to base Class
A pointer to a base Class shall only be cast to a pointer to a derived Class by means of 'dynamic_cast'
An unconditional 'throw', 'return' or 'break' shall terminate every non-empty switch-clause
Assignment operator should assign all non-static members of the target object
Avoid using 'using namespace' or 'using' declarations in header files
Do not return a dereferenced pointer allocated inside the function
Do not alter a control variable in the body of a 'for' statement
Never define collection of 'std::auto_ptr'
Avoid using 'class' or 'struct' parameters with variadic Functions
Avoid using 'new[]', prefer 'std::vector' or 'std::array'
Casting from pointer to base Class to pointer to derived Class should be done through 'dynamic_cast' or 'static_cast'
Avoid using "continue" statement
"enum" members other than the first one should not be explicitly initialized unless all members are explicitly initialized.
Ensure that dynamically allocated memory on local pointer in functions/methods is freed.
Avoid iterator invalidation.
Avoid use of unvalidated input in array indexing and memory allocation
Ensure that you are not using <cstdio> library
Avoid using 'setjmp' or 'longjmp' (C/C++)
Avoid using the library functions bsearch and qsort from <stdlib.h> (C/C++)
Prefer using strto*() from core linrary instead of atol, atoll, atoi, atof from stdlib.h for a more robust string handling
Avoid using offsetof from <cstddef>
Ensure that you do not use implementation-dependent <ctime> library
Avoid using <stdio.h> (C/C++)
Make sure you do not use <time.h> to avoid unexpected and implementation dependent outcome
Ensure that a class type exception is always be caught by reference to avoid slicing
Ensure that Switch statements have at least 2 case clauses
All if … else if constructs shall be terminated with an else clause (C/C++)
Ensure to declare arrays with a defined size
Esnure that the exceptions are thrown by value
Ensure to not use //, /* within comments
Avoid using 'signal.h' (C/C++)
Make sure to not use unnamed namespaces in header files so that results are as expected
Ensure to return a proper expression for a non-void function
Ensure that in global space only extern linkages, namespace and main function are present
Avoid using the unbounded functions of <cstring> library
Where multiple handlers are provided in a single try-catch statement or function-try-block, any ellipsis (catch-all) handler shall occur last.
Ensure to separate a side effect of an expression from the sizeof method
Prefer using Integers rather than Octal Constants
Do not override the standard library functions (C/C++)
Ensure to handle exceptions inside main()
Ensure that there is at least one exception handler to catch-all otherwise unhandled exceptions in the main function(C++)
Ensure to use an integral value to iterate in loops
Ensure that testing floating point numbers for equality is not used as is source of imprecision
Ensure to split the expressions and assignments into multiple lines for better readability and maintainability.
Avoid having  a method call or additional expressions in a statement using "++" or "--" operators (C/C++)
Avoid using Digraphs (C++)
Avoid using Trigraphs
Avoid using Unions
All constructors that are callable with a single argument of fundamental type shall be declared explicit.
Avoid declaring data members in non-POD classes as public or protected
A base class shall be declared virtual only if it is used in a diamond hierarchy
Ensure to use C++ style notation casts to avoid unexpected type conversions
Handlers of a function-try-block implementation of a class constructor ordestructor shall not reference non-static members from this class or its bases.
Ensure that you do not convert a function pointer to any other type to avoid unexpected behavior
Ensure that pointer types are not cast to integral types
Member functions shall not return non-const handles to class-data.
Ensure that you use 'enum' types with  [ ], =, == and !=, the unary & operator, and <, <=, >, >=.
Ensure to have boolean operands with boolean operators
Avoid having expressions with bool type to be used as operands on operators other than =, &&, ||, !, ==, !=, the unary & operator, and the conditional operator
Avoid dynamic_cast to convert current object to its derived class from its constructor or destructor
Avoid delete operators to exit with an exception.
Avoid move constructor and move assignment operator to exit with an exception
Avoid checking Integer overflow without explicit cast
Converting a multiplication to a larger type should be done before the multiplication takes place
Avoid comparing types of different widths in a loop
Bit-fields shall be either unsigned integral, or enumeration (with underlying type of unsigned integral type).
Ensure arrays and containers are accessed using unsigned values
Avoid lines starting with "#" with invalid pre-processing directive
Undefined macro identifiers shall not be used in #if or #elif preprocessor directives, except as operands to the defined operator
Arguments to a function-like macro shall not contain tokens that look like preprocessing directives.
Avoid using # OR ## operators more than once while defining macros
Prefer defining macros in Global Namespace
Avoid using goto to jump backwards into a statement in the same function(C/C++)
Mke sure you do not have unused labels in your code
Avoid defining, redefining or undefining standard macros from standard library
Avoid using typeid in polymorphic class from the body of its constructor or destructor.
Ensure using ANSI standard Operators such as <>,<=,>= in SQL where clauses to ensure portability
